riod they appear largely to have abided by these restrictions. Of the 798
rebel actions against army units reported from April to October, there was
an average of one death for every four events, and one injury per event.
Fewer than 7 percent of the rebel confrontations with the armed forces
during these seven months reported any deaths or injuries. When casual-
ties were reported, they averaged 4 deaths and 17injuries,well below the
comparable estimates for armed factionalbattles. Clashes with army units
would become much more dangerous in1968,when soldiers were once
again given the authority to use force, but during the high point of 1967
the toll from rebel confrontations with army units was still relatively low.
